text: It's my honor to introduce our two distinguished speakers today. Abbas El Gamal, the Hitachi America professor in
the School of Engineering and professor in the Department of Electrical Engineering at Stanford. He's also the recipient of numerous awards,
including the 2016 Richard W Hamming Medal, and the 2012 Claude E Shannon Award.
His research spans several areas including network information theory, field-programmable gate arrays, and digital imaging devices and systems.
His research group is currently involved in projects in smart grids. Ram Rajagopal, is an assistant Professor of
Civil and Environmental Engineering at Stanford University, associate professor of Civil and Environmental Engineering at
Stanford University and the founder and director of the Stanford Sustainable Systems Lab. He specializes in creating and deploying large sensing systems and using
the generated data together with novel statistical algorithms and stochastic control,
to achieve sustainable transportation, energy, and infrastructure networks. So with that, I'm going to hand the presentation over to Abbas and Ram.
Hi. Um, first, we're going to tell you a little bit about why we decided to offer this course.
Uh, and then we'll talk about, er, the course itself, and then in the last part,
we're going to give you very brief, uh, descr- very brief overview of
battery systems and their applications in transportation and grid services.
And highlight uh, some of the content of the course.
The high level of motivation for offering this course and for our research in general,
is climate change, which is caused by carbon emissions from burning fossil fuels.
Transportation and electricity generation contribute the majority of these types of carbon emissions, and, um,
high capacity battery systems which have been developed recently are playing
a very a importa- a key role actually in curbing- carbon emissions through electrification of transportation,
and by addressing the renewable energy variability.
So if you look at the curriculum for battery systems,
existing courses such as these ones from Stanford offer excellent in-depth understanding of some aspects of battery systems.
However, because battery systems is highly interdisciplinary and applied in nature,
there is no course that takes a holistic system oriented approach, uh, to battery systems. So that's one of the things that we,
uh, want to- to accomplish with this course.
In addition to the, um, curricular need,
um, there is one more reason we specifically decided to teach this class.
Storage systems have been playing a major role in our research work on the new grid.
So here in the figure, you can see the traditional grid structure. So we have generation supplying power to consumers,
and power flows from left to right on this figure. Um, in a traditional grid,
we don't have, uh, storage, therefore, generation has to meet demand at every point in time.
But the grid is changing significantly. In the supply side,
we are seeing the adoption of renewables, wind, and solar for example, as well as the addition of transmission scale storage.
On the consumer side, behind the meter, we're seeing the adoption of,
uh, rooftop PVs, smart appliances, and electric vehicles.
One kind of an important question is, how can we use all of these resources in order to support the rest of the ecosystem?
To do that, you need to account for various considerations.
First, the fact that if we wanna coordinate all these elements, we need to account for cyber constraints.
Second, we need to account for the preferences of consumers, and third, for all the physical network constraints.
And this is kind of, has been a key driving question of the research we have been doing here at Stanford.
And one important point is, as we design systems that can do this type of
coordination for EV charging or for distributed energy resources in homes and buildings,
um, we need realistic and detailed resource models. And as I mentioned earlier,
battery storage is an important resource, but in EV charging, the battery inside the car is another resource.
So since 2016, we have been doing this project called Powernet,
which is all about how to use the Cloud to coordinate resources in the home.
It's a project in partnership with Google, Sonnen, a battery systems company, SunTech Drive,
a motor systems company, and the Navy. The project has kind of four important elements.
Um, I'll start with the Home Hub which is kind of an intelligence that sits in the home and comm- communicates to all of the local resources.
One of these local resources is a smart panel that has power electronics that's set in the home,
and is designed at Stanford. Now, the Home Hub uses its local intelligence to optimize what the storage,
EV charging, solar, can do for the home, and accounts for all of the customer preferences.
Now, we may want to coordinate resources across homes to achieve goals such as shaving the peak,
or automating the response to prices, and in order to do that from the Cloud,
we have a Cloud coordinator which does a planning step a day in advance.
So those are the two kind of main components of Powernet. Let's see in a little bit more detail what's inside.
When we're designing this planning intelligence in Powernet, we have to account for four major constraints, customer preferences,
the network physics, meaning the power network constraints,
the delays or the cyber constraints. So in- in this figure,
you can see it's represented as a delay in obtaining data from the edge of the grid. Um, and finally, the fourth one and very important one is,
when major resource that we utilize to achieve our goals is storage, and we need accurate models for storage.
One, for capturing its aging and incorporating that as part of the cost, and two,
for understanding if I send a signal to storage, how it responds, and incorporating that in all the algorithms.
As I mentioned before, we also have designed, um, with, uh, faculty such as professor Juan Rivas who will also be teaching in our course, um,
a power electronics device, a smart dimmer fuse that can be used to control the panel in your home.
Um, various types of algorithms use data generated by all the systems to make decisions,
and then we're building several types of test beds. The first one I wanna mention is the Power-net Lab.
This is a lab we have in Stanford in the Y2E2 building, and it basically has two homes setup in this lab.
One of the homes has real appliances, fridges, dishwasher, air conditioner,
water heater, a solar panel on the rooftop, and actually battery storage device as you can
see there there from Tesla in this particular case. And then the other home has the ability to emulate various loads.
Both homes are connected to the real distribution and transmission systems, and we have the electronics to do that.
All of these homes can be used for simulating real-world conditions and testing algorithms.
And hopefully some of the data from this lab will be available for our class for students to utilize in projects.
Together with our initial test bed, we built field tests.
So right now, we have the applied power net in a farm. You can see there on the left-hand side on the bottom picture,
that gray housing contains the battery storage that is used in
managing solar power to cool a barn where milk production is happening.
So we have seen tremendous potential for utilizing such technologies through reducing costs in dairy farms.
In another test bed, we are have recruited 35 homes here in the Bay area that we'll have,
uh, solar storage, electric vehicles and we will show the power of coordination. Okay.
In this first project, we saw a lot about how to coordinate the stationary batteries in the context
of distributed energy resources and responding to the prices and commands.
But how about charging? So charging is really about coordinating mobile batteries.
And we just started a new project and program here at the Stanford called EV50,
and the goal of this is to figure out how to coordinate charging,
particularly fast charging that generates incredible demands for the grid.
And both by using deferrable charging capabilities as well as potentially storage.
And again, you have to account for the potential for two-way charging, the multiple stakeholders in
this coordination exercise that range from the car companies, the car owner, the charging company and the utility as well as various use cases.
For example, having a fleet of autonomous vehicles offering ride sharing services,
versus deliveries, versus individually owned cars. To do- for doing all this,
we definitely need not just a detailed model of the grid, but a detailed understanding of the battery systems.
So this has been a very strong motivator for us to teach this course.
Well I'll like to tell you a little bit about, ah, the course itself.
So the course provides a systems approach to studying, ah, battery systems, ah,
rather than, ah, and, um, ah, one of it's components.
Ah, so to cover the various multidisciplinary and real world aspects of various systems,
we decided on, ah, a mixture of a seminar and a regular course. Um, so it's a little bit of un- unorthodox,
ah, course in that sense. Ah, like a course, topics are streamlined,
so in a seminar you typically have, ah, random set of, ah, um, lectures about various topics.
Here we actually try to streamline the, ah, the lectures so that, ah, starting from basics and moving on to real-world system considerations and case studies.
Ah, like a seminar however we, ah, to cover the breadth of the subject, ah,
we've lined up an amazing set of experts in various aspects of battery systems including, ah, academics, ah,
five professors from Stanford other than Ram and myself, ah, and two from other universities, ah,
two experts from national labs: NREL and SANDIA, ah, and then, ah, experts from industry: Waymo,
Tesla, EPRI, EVGo, and Battery Design.
The course, ah, when we set it up, it's really intended to mezzanine level undergraduate and graduate students in
engineering and related fields as well as engineers professionals in industry who are interested in designing battery systems,
ah, doing research on battery systems, applying them to transportation and the grid,
ah, or just simply learning about battery systems. The course can be taken as a one unit credit no credit only seminar in which case, ah,
the student doesn't really need to have any, ah, particular prerequisite to take the class except some,
kind of, ah, ah, engineering background for example. Ah, it can also be taken as a 3-unit letter grade only seminar, plus a project.
In which case, we wanna make sure that the students who decides to take it, ah, for a gra- for a later grade,
that the project that the students, ah, is, er, is going to do, um,
is something that he has the background to do. So, so, ah, that the prerequisites really has to do with the project,
ah, not the course itself. For example if you wanted to do a project
involving electrochemistry or, or, or materials, you need to have some background in, in,
in electrochemistry and material science in order for us to say, yeah, that's, that's seems like a good match. [NOISE] Okay. So, um,
I'm grouping- we group the, the topics of the class, ah, as follows. Um, in the first- roughly speaking,
in the first part of the course, we're gonna talk about the battery systems themselves. Ah, so we're gonna talk about, ah,
the materials, the battery cell, power electronics, um, ah,
and battery system management. In the second part of the, of the course,
again roughly speaking, we're gonna be talking about some, ah, system considerations, ah, such as modeling, degradation, ah, thermal management,
safety, and finally something about economics of batteries.
And then in the third part will be, ah, about, ah, applications in electric vehicles,
and, and the grid. Ah, there is a detailed syllabus I believe is posted on the SCPD web page,
which, ah, lists, ah, the lecture, ah, tentative titles and, ah, the speakers.
So you can actually see the- these topics mapped, ah, to these source.
So in the remaining part of the webinar, we're going to tell you a little bit about various systems, and,
ah, their applications in transportation and the grid.
Um, so, ah, the, the graph on the left here, which you can't see very well unfortunately,
but it basically shows that tremendous- shows two things: One is that battery systems are extremely old technology.
Ah, it started in the, ah, 19th century and maybe earlier even 18th century,
and over time and driven by various applications, the energy density, ah, which is the, ah,
watts hour per kilogram have been, ah, increasing as the application needs, ah,
until and then in 1992, there was a huge, ah, jump in energy density, ah,
by the development of lithium ion batteries. And these were actually,
these were actually, um, ah, driven by, ah, portable electronics revolution.
And today, there are 2.7 billion, um, ah, mobile phones that use,
ah, lithium ion batteries. The improvements in, ah, battery,
ah, is not limited only to density- energy density,
but also to power density, ah, which here you can see it in terms of, ah,
ah, watts per liter or watts per kilogram.
And, ah, because of these improvements in addition to the improvement in, um, in, ah,
energy density, ah, the automotive and grid services applications,
ah, became ah, ah, feasible. So on the left here,
I'm showing a graph, ah, which is the market size for,
ah, shows that the, the market size for lithium ion batteries has been, ah, dramatically increasing.
And more interestingly, ah, the projection is that the lithium ion batteries will be a $550 billion market,
most of which, ah, are for, ah, transportation and, ah, for, ah, grid storage.
Now, let me tell you a little bit about batteries themselves. So, ah, the, the basic,
ah, component of a battery is the battery cell, ah, which consists of an- an- anode,
a cathode, and a, ah, separator in between them. Um, and, ah, the self chemistry which is, ah,
the choices of materials and, and chemistry is for the anode, the cathode, and the separator, ah, determines the key characteristics of the battery such as rated voltage, energy density,
power density, and, ah, self discharge rate and, and, and thermal, ah, properties.
Um, and on the right here you see, ah, the basic, ah, packages in which, ah, the cells come in.
Um, there is a incredibly diverse set of chemistry used in lithium ion, ah, batteries.
And in the class you're going to uh, hear more about this, and about, ah, the,
ah, the how the cells are designed.
The main advantages of lithium ion battery as we alluded to, um, is high voltage,
uh, high power, and improved density. But, uh, lithium ion batteries have some, uh,
important limitations, um, er, which have to do with the high sensitivity to overcharging,
um, and to the outside, er, temperature, uh, which affect capacity and,
and discharged power, but they also are very important considerations for safety.
Um, another aspect- another limitation is that aging, um, and, uh, which is not completely well understood.
And again, it can lead to, uh, safety issues. And you will hear about these in detail in the class.
Batteries, uh, more than a cell. Um, first, the batteries are- first that the, er,
cells are arranged in series and parallel to achieve the voltage and, er,
power and, um, energy requirement, er, of the application.
Um, and then the modules are arranged, uh, into the battery system itself together with power electronics, er,
thermal management, er, er, types of, uh, mechanical design.
Uh, and these are all managed using the battery management system.
And again, we're gonna talk about, er, we're gonna talk about this in detail,
uh, in the class. Now, let's go into a couple of applications on [NOISE] battery,
uh, battery systems, we wanna start with transportation. So 17 million, um,
EVs per year are expected to be sold by 2040, that roughly corresponds to 85 percent of the cars in the road.
EVs present advantages which go beyond them being green. Uh, one of them is that you have
a much higher energy conversion efficiency as compared to internal combustion engines,
and they have lower maintenance costs. The evolution of the lithium ion batteries
in terms of the power density and energy density is actually enabling these electric vehicles to achieve
similar range as what we see today in gasoline powered cars. And here, we can see kind of a typical configuration in
which kind of electric vehicles are built. This is called the skateboard platform.
You can see the battery system right there, um, and it's connected to a drive train and has power electronics to manage the charging,
um, as well as the connection to the drive train. The battery pack itself is very similar to what Professor El gamal showed before,
except it is gonna have a much more robust thermal and,
uh, mechanical, um, management compo- components.
And one of the keys in when you're kind of designing the battery system for a car is
that you need to account for speci- specific characteristics regarding lifespan,
safety, cost, performance, and the energy density and power density needs of the battery system for a car.
And this is kind of a key aspect that we wanna bring into our class. Another important aspect is how do we design the battery management system
itself to satisfy the needs of the automotive app- applications? We're bringing several speakers from academia and industry to explain these to us.
Another important issue for electric vehicles is how you refuel them or charging.
And the increase in level three charging, that's the fastest charging rates you see out there,
will result on dramatic impacts in terms of power in the grid. And unless we figure out ways to coordinate this charging,
this will represent a, a- enormous issue for scaling the adoption of electric vehicles.
So we mentioned earlier, the EV50 project that we have started at Stanford is addressing some of that.
But charging and its impacts will also be a key aspects that we will address in the class.
Finally, um, batteries, when they reach about 70 percent of their capacity to aging,
um, they need [NOISE] to be recycled. And actually, the way that happens is you not just have recycling,
you have reused, re-fabrication, and even reselling. And so this whole life cycle process of the batteries
is something we will have a lecture on in our course, and it's very critical to the industry.
Now, just a brief overview of battery systems for the grid and for particularly,
your- for grid services. So grid storage, which is the ability to store electricity
now and use it later has been increasing dramatically. And you can see here in the figures that lithium ion batteries
corresponds to a lion's share of that increase in terms of energy and power.
Storage is used in many different places in the grid. So in this figure, you can see it's used with generators.
For example, to support our applications such as outage management, uh, directly connected to the transmission system to participate in the wholesale markets.
Connected at the substation to help manage the distribution network for utility. Connected at the secondary transformer, um, again,
to help the utilities and finally customers may own batteries to kind of do their own,
um, demand management or build management. The location and type of storage,
and it determines what applications they can be used for, and we have, as I mentioned earlier,
various different types of applications. This is an important aspect of the user storage, [NOISE] and particularly,
the battery systems for storage, and we will have experts on, on this topic speaking in our course.
One specific application we wanted to highlight is regarding support for renewable generation.
So the adoption of renewables is- causes sig- significant issues for the grid.
On the left-hand side, you can see in dark blue, the demand profile here in California for this summer,
I picked a day in the summer. And the curve that you see is called a duck curve, which means there is a significant ramping towards
the end of the afternoon when the sun starts to set. We need- the increasing adoption of solar will just exacerbate this issue.
And if we add more and more renewables, you might end up with situations like what is shown on the figure in
the right-hand side where we have a Texas system with 50 percent renewables.
And because of the production of these renewables, we expect a lot of curtailment.
So it's about 30 terawatt hours of energy for a year in curtailments due to the variability that renewables are causing.
Storage provides a very good option for addressing both of these issues.
First, in the duck curve, storage can be used for storing energy during the,
the hours where the sun is shining and then using that energy in later hours of the day,
eliminating those ramping issues. And second, in a grid where you have significant amount of renewables,
just four hours of storage for examp- duration can prov- can allow you to recover in this particular Texas case,
28 terawatt hours of energy. And the capacity of the storage that's needed is only 14 gigawatts.
So one key takeaway from these two studies, um, is that short duration storage [NOISE] can solve a lot of these issues so within a day.
And battery systems turn out to be a very attractive proposition for sh- short duration storage.
So here, we are seeing the drive and the predictions in terms of adoption of battery technology for storage.
And you can see, it's expected to grow a lot up to 35 gigawatts by 2030- gigawatt hours by 2030.
Many design battery systems for storage for the grid.
You need to take into account considerations such as safety, cost, performance, and the lifespan.
Particularly, safety and cost are primary concerns. And we're gonna have experts in our class talk about the design of
battery systems specifically for storage applications. Thank you very much.
And, uh, we will go forward. So with that, I want to turn it over back over to Abbas and Ram.
We have a lot of questions that are coming in. I think the first one to ask that came in is just a- to circle back maybe,

uh, to the purpose of the course. And just again, and you touched on already, but developing a little bit further, if you are- if someone is a working professional in a particular area battery systems,
what do you think is the- what is the importance of this course for them, and, and what will they take away from it? Say they're working on materials or electrical chemistry?
Um, I think these are the exactly the type of people we designed this course for which is to give, er,
kind of an A to Z, um, view of battery systems.
Um, and even if you're working on a very specific area in batteries, it really helps a lot to put it in context so that you know how what you're
doing affects the applications and how the unhealthy application requirements affect your work.
So, er, it's clearly something that will give you a very broad background on
battery systems that would be extremely helpful if you're working on even if you're working on a very specific area in,
in, in, in or in applications of course. And would this apply to say someone who is an economist or
a publicly policy expert who is working in this field as well? Will this bring value to their background?
I think so. Uh, we're having, um, speakers who have those backgrounds as well,
um, engineering economics for example. And I think how this will apply for them is having a little bit of
understanding of what battery systems technologies are capable of, at what stage of their evolution they're in,
and what are the future potential will help inform a lot of that work.
Thank you. We have a lot of very specific questions about battery systems. So I'm gonna jump into those.
One that came up a lot are the, the sort of waste products of creating batteries,
and is that something that will be addressed in the course and do you have any comments or thoughts on that from your own research?
Um, I di- brought in a speaker who will be speaking
specifically about their own research on this topic of recycle and reuse.
Um, what we- we are also learning on this topic, um, and it seems to be a key question for
automakers and storage manufacturers in the world today. I think it's- it's one of those topics which is emerging, uh,
because store- uh, the, uh, battery systems are still relatively new. And you don't have a lot of ones that are not in use already.
Uh people are starting to think about what to do with the batteries when the capacity
degrades below a certain percentage like 70 percent in the case of cars and then a lot of ideas emerging.
So it's not an established area in which we can have, uh, several speakers.
It's just that it's an emerging area. You're going to hear about it towards the end of the class and,
uh, it could be an area where somebody would be interested in a project for example. And it's important to note that one of the key aspects of recycling or

detail and the systems understanding in the course. Correct. Maybe re- uh, related to that or building off that question.
Uh, we got a few questions about- it sounds like the course is focusing on lithium ion batteries.

Is that also a technology that you think has promise in these applications? Uh, we are probably not the right people to,

um, uh, you know, Yi Cui and, um, and Will Chueh from Stanford will be talking about,

We're not sure, uh, who exactly is going to talk about it. So but, yes. I mean I'm sure it will come up.
And- and- and always again the battery electrochemistry is one only one piece of this puzzle.
How it fits with the rest of the system understanding that in the case of lithium ion will certainly help you understand what you need to do

So it's not like it's a different technology. It's just a better way of, uh,
instead of the separators that we use now, of use solid separators which improves safety.
But it's still lithium ions. Will you touch on any other kinds of, uh, storage.
So there are a couple that are coming out. The one that was mentioned a few times, flywheel energy storage. Is that outside-
No. We decided- so we- this is an excellent question actually because, um, from the very beginning we decided to focus on, uh,
battery systems and more specifically on lithium, you know, high-capacity, uh, systems.
Um, in- in part because you can't really cover everything well.

If it is with the generator typically is a couple of megawatts. If it is at the building, you know,
it's going to be in the hundreds of kilowatt hours or, you know. And if it is in the transmission system,

battery systems in terms of safety for example, which is one of the most important aspect.

All of these are people, you know, like degradation for example still an area of research.
So some of the stuff you're going to hear about is really, uh, state of the art.
A lot of it. Not- it's not just all classical style, but some of it is- is still open.
And that's why we decided to have projects because, uh, people can look at some of these issues in more detail on.
And- and it's worth pointing out kind of the reason we chose the structure for the class is that it allowed
not just academics coming in and speaking about the topic on the cutting edge of the research but also people who are building
products in the real world or taking that academic research and transforming into actual engineered system that scale.
So you're going to have both points of view and a little broader understanding of all these issues.
And that's what we mean by, uh, systems approach. We look at the whole thing. You don't look at just one aspect of it and- and- and just spend
the whole- which- which is very important for people who are working on such aspect like fear of designing a cell.
You do need to take the classes that talk about- you need strong background in chemistry and material science as well.
So that doesn't take away from any- any of these components. So if you- if you are going to design the power electronics,
you need to be an expert in power electronics. You cannot just take our course and design power electronics.
So- but we wanted to just give people a broad exposure so that they say,
"Oh I see how this affects this and what the issues are and- and- and what the impact of certain things will be on other things."
That kinda. So that's what I mean by systems. And it's very unusual to have this type of systems
oriented classes in universities in general. It's something that most the industry does.
So we're bringing some of that in the- So it can be a good segue to just build on- on the project itself.
Um, so few questions coming in about that. When students enter the class, do they need to have a project to mind or is that
